Problem:
Analyze an electrical circuit in which the current \\( I(t) \\) over time t is driven by a complex function of voltage \\( V(t) = e^{i\\omega t} \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is the radian frequency. We explore how applying a Laplace transform to the voltage affects the current's behavior and the system's response.

If at time \\( t_0 \\) a filter is applied that modifies \\( V(t) \\) to \\( V'(t)=V(t)e^{-\\alpha t} \\) where \\( \\alpha \\) is a damping coefficient, will the resultant transformed current \\( \hat{I}'(s) \\) reflect only the properties of the filter applied and not the original \\( V(t) \\)?
Explanation: The intervention with the filter changes the voltage input but the resultant current in the Laplace domain, \\( \hat{I}'(s) \\), not only reflects the properties of the filter but also integrates the effects of the original voltage. Both \\( V(t) \\) and the filter's influence are represented in \\( \hat{I}'(s) \\).
